For what it is worth I’m back in and buying heavy now. Trading at 9 x the lowest estimate on the street now.
Someone has an interest and is working this hard to shake out and wear out positions. Bottom is almost in.

First, congratulations to all longs. I guess we know why the price was being kept low until now! Second, for those asking what to do, you have two options:1) You can hold on to your shares until the deal is official, likely several months away. You are promised $18 minimum, no matter what and the shares will turn to cash when it's done. 2) You can sell your shares. The price will likely reflect the risk of the merger being rejected by some unforeseen issue, so it will never get quite to $18 until it's a done deal. It is likely not to move much from now, although it should continue to slowly rise towards $18 until the summer.It is probably wisest to sell soon and find your next big winner, but the choice is yours. Great investing with you and GLTA!
I have had enough I am gonna make some calls and get the squeeze going this week. Get out of the way or lose

Really nice earnings once again. Have to see what the market thinks but they are now trading at 7x 2020 earnings and .5x sales with revenue growth of 30-40%. They also have zero debt if you back out the store leases. Not sure what else to say other than this should be a $25 stock.
I heard SPWH buyout is being renegotiated to 28 bucks a share, much more fair although still not full value.
How hasn't this stock popped? Their financials look great! Revenue and profits are increasing and it seems they have paid down a lot of their long term debt. Going long on this one.
Should have sold this months ago and bought the other outdoor stocks whose price have appreciated significantly. The buyout has really hurt us shareholders. Company was sold way too cheap.
Sell SPWH buy BGFV the mother of all squeezes is coming on Set 17

Not that it matters to the market but first price target increase is out this morning from Lake St. Lake Street analyst Mark Smith raised the firm's price target on Sportsman's Warehouse to $23.50 from $22 and keeps a Buy rating on the shares after the company reported third quarter sales and earnings that beat his estimates and consensus forecasts. Continued demand and market share gains led to same-store-sales growth of 40.9% that was driven by strength across all product categories, Smith noted.
Any idea what is going on here? Seems a very odd drop with a buyout price of $18.00. Maybe something is up?

The action on this stock is very strange for an $18 buyout that is scheduled to close by years end. One could theoretically buy at 17.65 and get a 2% return in less than 3 months - that's over 8% annualized.

Not once during the call did management get asked or talked about enhancing shareholder valueWith al the excess cash flow there needs to be a share buyback or dividend institutedBoth would go a long way towards short attacks and improving future earnings
Deal should have been worth more that $18.00 per share. Bass Pro is getting a steal on this company.
Wow what a pay day! Good stuff for everyone that held on there.
just reported awesome earnings of $1.57 vs .77 and and way above the .48 estimate

Sportsman's Warehouse (SPWH - Research Report) came out with quarterly earnings of $0.76 per share, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $0.32 per share. This compares to earnings of $0.13 per share a year ago. These figures are adjusted for non-recurring items.This quarterly report represents an earnings surprise of 137.50%. A quarter ago, it was expected that this outdoor sporting goods specialty retailer would post a loss of $0.06 per share when it actually produced earnings of $0.01, delivering a surprise of 116.67%.Over the last four quarters, the company has surpassed consensus EPS estimates three times.Sportsman's Warehouse, which belongs to the Zacks Retail - Apparel and Shoes industry, posted revenues of $380.99 million for the quarter ended July 2020, surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 33.66%. This compares to year-ago revenues of $211.77 million. The company has topped consensus revenue estimates four times over the last four quarters.The sustainability of the stock's immediate price movement based on the recently-released numbers and future earnings expectations will mostly depend on management's commentary on the earnings call.Sportsman's Warehouse shares have added about 118.1% since the beginning of the year versus the S&P 500's gain of 9.2%.What's Next for Sportsman's Warehouse?While Sportsman's Warehouse has outperformed the market so far this year, the question that comes to investors' minds is: what's next for the stock?There are no easy answers to this key question, but one reliable measure that can help investors address this is the company's earnings outlook. Not only does this include current consensus earnings expectations for the coming quarter(s), but also how these expectations have changed lately.Empirical research shows a strong correlation between near-term stock movements and trends in earnings estimate revisions. Investors can track such revisions by themselves or rely on a tried-and-tested rating tool like the Zacks Rank, which has an impressive track record of harnessing the power of earnings estimate revisions.Ahead of this earnings release, the estimate revisions trend for Sportsman's Warehouse was favorable. While the magnitude and direction of estimate revisions could change following the company's just-released earnings report, the current status translates into a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) for the stock. So, the shares are expected to outperform the market in the near future. You can see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.It will be interesting to see how estimates for the coming quarters and current fiscal year change in the days ahead. The current consensus EPS estimate is $0.33 on $280.80 million in revenues for the coming quarter and $0.91 on $1.10 billion in revenues for the current fiscal year.Investors should be mindful of the fact that the outlook for the industry can have a material impact on the performance of the stock as well. In terms of the Zacks Industry Rank, Retail - Apparel and Shoes is currently in the bottom 10% of the 250 plus Zacks industries. Our research shows that the top 50% of the Zacks-ranked industries outperform the bottom 50% by a factor of more than 2 to 1.
